name: Vivi T
comment info:
Lebron James Breaks Records With His Career Points in 2023. 

Lebron James has the highest career points out of anyone else featured on the graph. His points have reached 38,390, the next closest player (Kareem Abdul-Jabbar) only reached 38,387. Though these points are close, Labron is still the highest out of all 250.  On the x-axis of the graph is the player's age, and the y-axis has how many careers points the player has gained while in the NBA. The graph also uses a purple color to differentiate between players that are currently in the league vs previous NBA players. The graph also includes only the top 250 scorers. This graph can help current players in the NBA keep track of how their career points compare to other players, and how their trajectory compares. This can also apply to basketball players in our community at Eden Prairie High School. We wonder who collects the data and how they keep track of the data. How do they judge what specifically is a career point? How will Labron’s career look after he finally retires?

name: Noah V.
comment info:
What do you notice? 
I noticed that the slope of Lebron James lines is substantially steeper, showing that he scored more points per game on average than Kareem Abdul-Jabbar did. LeBron and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar both have identical overall scoring totals, however Abdul-Jabbar didn't catch up to LeBron until he was about 42 years old. One can see  that from his rookie season to year 20, Lebron has been the most consistent scorer.

What do you wonder?
When Lebron reaches the same age as Kareem from the moment in his career when he scored the most points, I wonder what his point average will be. I also wonder if the players on your squad have any bearing on your ability to score points. Lebron and Kareem were receiving assists and support from others, so they weren't scoring all by themselves. I'm curious to know if their scoring streaks reduced after being traded or switched to different teams.

How does this relate to you and your community?
This is relevant to my town because many young people in my city aspire to play in the NBA, and it demonstrates that you can surpass the scoring leader you were raised knowing if you put in a lot of effort and dedication. It relates to my generation and how we are innovating and growing younger while achieving goals that others who came before us accomplished at a more older age.

comment info:
1.) One thing I noticed is that LeBron James is now the NBA's all -time leading scorer. This is crazy to think about, as I have watched LeBron James almost half of his career, and have watched him play since I became a serious basketball fan in 2015. Another thing I noticed is that Rudy Gay is on this list. It's interesting because the graph claims he hit 17,500 points at age 36, and he is 36 right now. name: Moderator Wendy
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.   In New Jersey, there is either LeBron fever, a love of basketball or excellence in writing headlines, but six of the seven great headlines are from the Garden State.  
Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  "Lebron James: The Young NBA Career Scoring Leader” by Gabe of Auburn High School in Massachusetts; “LeBron James: Youngest with Most Career Points” by Colleen of Academy of Saint Elizabeth in Morristown, New Jersey; three from students at Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey -- “King James Reigns Supreme Amongst NBA’s Elite: Top 250 Scorers Announced!” by Cesar, "LeBron James Sweeps the Court: Will He Stay on Top?" by Alida, and “LeBron’s Journey to Becoming a Legend” by Michelle and two from New Jersey (no school name given) “LeBron James Shoots His Way Past Abdul-Jabbar and Straight Into History” by Kaitlin and “New King in Town: LeBron Takes the Crown for Highest Career Points” by Isabella.
You can continue to post responses.  Please check back by Friday, Feb. 17 to see the Reveal with the free link to the original New York Times article with its six graphs, some questions about this graph and a few Stat Nuggets.
The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, Feb. 17 with moderation on Wednesday, March 1.  The topic – the earthquake affecting Turkey and Syria.    
Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who marvels in sports that she cannot do, and Wendy Clark in Idaho cheering you on!
